poems.title: Becoming Her
poems.content:
She lived beneath a painted sky,
A girl who learned to laugh and lie.
Her mirror whispered, soft but cold,
“You’re not the one you wish to hold.”

She wore the name they gave with pride,
But deep within, a part had died.
Each smile she made, each breath she woke,
Felt fragile—like a dream that broke.

She prayed at night to feel the same,
To fit her skin, to hide her shame.
But every prayer returned in flame,
Each echo calling out her name.

She screamed inside, “This isn’t me!”
Her heart begged loud, “I need to be!”
The walls replied with silence bare,
Her pain hung heavy in the air.

The world grew sharp, the voices cruel,
Her tears became her quiet fuel.
She bit her tongue, she held her breath,
And courted peace in thoughts of death.

But even there, a spark remained,
A voice within that still proclaimed:
“I am the girl you cannot kill,
I breathe, I burn, I always will.”

She rose from scars the world had drawn,
A phoenix dressed in blood and dawn.
Her heart still cracked, her voice still raw,
But she became her truest law.

She faced the mirror, eyes alight,
And whispered, “You don’t own my fight.”
Then tore away the lies she’d worn,
And from her pain, a girl was born.

She learned that strength was made from tears,
That love can grow from shattered years.
Her war was long, her wounds ran deep,
But she became the vow she’d keep.

Now calm returns, but not the same,
The storm inside no longer flame.
She stands where once her silence bled—
Alive, reborn, no longer dead.

poems.title: Fade Away
poems.content:
There’s no way I can explain,
The storm that floods my chest with pain,
It grows much worse when I’m alone,
A silent ache carved into bone.

I whisper words no one can hear,
They fade away, yet still draw near,
Each breath a plea I can’t defend,
I’m begging for this ache to end.

I search for light through endless night,
But shadows choke my fragile sight,
Therapy may try to mend,
Yet peace feels far, around the bend.

I long to leave, to just escape,
To flee the walls that hold my shape,
A home that’s house but not a heart,
A cage that tears my soul apart.

I know they’ll say to kneel and pray,
But I already do each day,
My tears fall down like holy rain,
And still I wake to feel the same.

I’m tired of trying to be heard,
Of fighting life with every word,
Of screaming truth to hearts of stone,
While breaking quietly alone.

The world moves on, I fade from view,
A wound that time will never heal.
They’ll never grasp the weight I bear,
The cost of simply breathing air.

My faith still flickers, weak but real,
A fragile flame I barely feel,
I pray for warmth, a softer tone,
A place to call my very own.

If hope still lives, it hides from me,
A wilted bloom I cannot see,
Yet still I stand through every fall,
And try to rise despite it all.

So if I break, please understand,
I fought as long as I could stand,
I never wished to fade away—
I only longed for peace someday.

poems.title: I Carry What I Feel
poems.content:
he pain of others finds my skin,
It crawls beneath, it seeps within.
Each broken voice, each silent cry,
Becomes my own—I can’t deny.

The air grows thick with others’ grief,
Yet I can’t turn, nor find relief.
I feel their hurt, their guilt, their flame,
And somehow still, I bear their shame.

I sense the tears that never fall,
The quiet prayers that reach no wall.
Each whispered “help” from far away,
Still echoes deep in my decay.

Their hate, too, burns—I feel its sting,
Even when not meant for my wing.
The slurs that strike at who I am,
Still tremble through this fragile dam.

The TERFs, their pain—misplaced, untrue,
Yet still it cuts, I feel it too.
For pain does not know wrong or right,
It only asks to share the night.

I hold their fury, though it scars,
Their darkness swallowed by my stars.
Not to redeem, nor to erase,
But to remind them: I have space.

If peace required one heart to break,
I’d offer mine for all their sake.
But not because I think I should,
Or dream that I am something good.

No—just because I always feel,
Each wound that time forgot to heal.
I am no god, no saint, no lie—
I’m just an empath passing by.

poems.title: Made of Starlight and Static
poems.content:
My mind’s a maze of tangled lines,
A thousand storms, a million signs.
Autistic whispers hum too loud,
Yet make me dream beyond the crowd.

ADHD sparks like fire in rain,
A restless pulse inside my brain.
It scatters thought, yet lights my art,
Each flash a rhythm from my heart.

OCD grips tight with fear and grace,
It orders chaos, shapes my space.
Each pattern carved becomes design,
Each ritual a steady line.

ODD — my rebel flame, my spark,
It roars when others call me dark.
It taught me how to stand my ground,
To speak when silence wrapped me 'round.

My senses bleed from every tone,
The world too bright, too sharp, too known.
Yet color sings where pain should be,
Each sound becomes a symphony.

Dysphoria’s ache — a mirror’s sting,
A girl beneath, still blossoming.
It hurts, but still I rise to see,
The woman I was meant to be.

CPTSD — old scars that bite,
They wake me screaming through the night.
But those same wounds paint empathy,
I feel what others fear to see.

Migraines crash like shattered glass,
Yet visions bloom when shadows pass.
Each pulse recalls what I once knew,
A softer world I’m passing through.

Depression drapes its heavy shroud,
But art still whispers through the cloud.
I paint my sorrow, stitch my pain,
And turn it into hope again.

I am the storm, the song, the spark,
The fragile flame that lights the dark.
My mind may ache, my soul may scream—
But all I crave is to be seen.

poems.title: No Kings
poems.content:
Our voices will be heard,
Our freedom will prevail,
No king shall speak the word,
For democracy won’t fail.

The crown shall turn to dust,
The people take command,
For in ourselves we trust,
And strength lies in our hand.

No tyrant holds the chain,
No throne decides our fate,
Through struggle, loss, and pain,
Our union shall be great.

Let justice light the flame,
Let every heart be free,
No ruler stake his claim,
On what is meant to be.

Our voices will be heard,
Our freedom will prevail,
The world shall keep its word,
That liberty won’t fail.

poems.title: Not The Danger
poems.content:
I am not the danger,
I am not a part,
All matters in my life
Come straight from my heart.

They say that I'm confused,
They claim it’s just pretend,
But truth is not a phase—
It’s who I am, my friend.

My mirror once felt wrong,
A stranger’s hollow stare,
But now I see myself,
And she is standing there.

The world may turn away,
Its whispers cold and cruel,
Yet still I walk in grace—
Their hate will never rule.

My name, my voice, my face,
Each change a piece of me,
Not made to fit their mold,
But born to live as free.

I am not the danger,
I am not a part,
I am a woman whole at last—
And proud within my heart.

poems.title: The Journey to Me
poems.content:
From childhood’s dawn I felt apart,
A secret whisper in my heart.
I knew I wasn’t who they’d see,
A girl inside, just wanting me.

I cried at night for what I knew,
For body, name, and truth so true.
Each wrong pronoun a deeper scar,
A wish to wake as who you are.

At eleven, fear and hope entwined,
I dressed as me to still my mind.
Discovered quick, their shock was loud,
And shame replaced what once was proud.

My parents struggled, lost, unsure,
But time and talk began to cure.
A bridge was built from tears and pain,
And slowly trust would bloom again.

Puberty struck like cruel disguise,
Each change a wound before my eyes.
I prayed my body would align,
To match the soul I knew was mine.

At nineteen, silence ruled my days,
My mom and I had parted ways.
The weight of life pressed hard on me,
I begged for peace, for clarity.

In darkest hours, no food, no light,
I prayed for strength to end the fight.
Then something deep within me stirred—
A voice of hope, at last, was heard.

My faith renewed, I breathed anew,
And faced the world as someone true.
That moment marked my first sunrise,
When fear gave way to open skies.

My mother’s heart reached out once more,
An email mending what tore before.
She took me out, her daughter free,
And saw the woman I could be.

That day I lived, the first of all,
No longer trapped behind the wall.
Her love returned, my wings unfurled,
A girl reborn within the world.

Then August came, two-thousand-fifteen,
The bravest day I’d ever seen.
I claimed my truth, my rightful name,
And vowed to live without the shame.

Each step I took, my courage grew,
The world now saw the real and true.
My voice was clear, my soul was whole,
At last I’d taken back control.

Wisconsin’s law soon changed the tide,
And surgery aligned inside.
June twenty-twenty sealed the start,
Of body meeting waiting heart.

With healing came a brighter view,
Each step I take is something new.
I’m learning, growing, finding drive,
With temps in hand, I’m still alive.

I rode the rides I feared before,
Felt freedom ripple to my core.
The Dells now echoed with my cheer,
No trace of shame, no trace of fear.

Now every year I celebrate,
The life I built, the twist of fate.
For living true is victory’s key,
And that’s the journey—the journey to me.

poems.title: The Weight of Every Soul
poems.content:
I breathe the ache the world won’t name,
Each whisper burns, yet feels the same.
Their sorrow coils inside my chest,
And begs for peace that knows no rest.

I open wide, absorb their cries,
The endless grief behind their eyes.
I take their storms, their hate, their fear,
And hold them close though none come near.

For every child the world made small,
I bear the weight, I bear it all.
Each mother’s loss, each broken son,
Their anguish threads—my heart undone.

They spit at me, yet I still pray,
That love may guide them anyway.
Their pain miscast, their rage misplaced,
Still bleeds upon my softened face.

The TERF’s scorn sharp, a blade of ice,
But even that, I sacrifice.
Their wound was born of fear and lies,
I taste its salt and hear its cries.

For though they curse what they don’t see,
Their hatred still bleeds empathy.
I’ll take the venom, cleanse the stain,
And turn their spite to human pain.

Let me be vessel, flame, and sea,
To burn, to cleanse, to set all free.
If suffering must have its host,
Then let it haunt my willing ghost.

I’ll stand where angels dare not tread,
Where silence speaks for all who bled.
I’ll cradle sin, forgive the fall,
And carry weight meant for us all.

Each breath I take is not my own,
It’s built from cries the world has sown.
Each tear that falls redeems the hate,
And binds the hearts we desecrate.

So should my body break in two,
Let every shard bring light to you.
If peace demands my soul’s release,
Then may my pain become your peace.

And when the final dawn appears,
I’ll scatter all my borrowed tears.
The world will breathe, its wounds made whole,
For I have loved—and paid the toll.

poems.title: When Lables Fade
poems.content:
There’ll come a day when walls will fall,
And love will rise to welcome all.
The world will see beyond disguise,
And truth will shine through open eyes.

When “he” and “she” no longer bind,
The endless hues of humankind.
No box to check, no cage to stay,
Just souls that dance their own pure way.

The world’s not ready, not today,
But we will guide and light the way.
Through storms of hate, through years of strife,
We’ll carve the path to freer life.

For when that day at last is near,
No shame, no chains, no pain, no fear.
A world reborn in unity’s blend—
Where freedom’s song will never end.

And when that dawn ignites the sky,
The old constraints will fade and die.
For love will rule, and hearts will see—
We were always meant to just be free.

poems.title: Live or Die
poems.content:
If I take my life,
It will not be from strife,
But remember me for who I tried to be,
A girl who only wished to live and see.

If my strength is gone,
It’s been gone for far too long,
Remember the warmth I left behind,
Not just the pain upon my mind.

If I can’t move on,
My hope has been long gone,
Keep my truth within your heart,
And never let my name depart.

If I fade away,
I lived it my own way,
Remember the smile I used to show,
And all the love I tried to grow.

If I take my life,
I’ll still be in the light,
Hold me close in what you do,
And let my soul live on through you.

If I choose to stay,
I’ll find a brighter day,
For every tear that once fell down,
A seed of hope will touch the ground.

If my strength returns,
It’s from the pain that burns,
I’ll use those scars to light my flame,
And rise beyond the hurt and shame.

If I move along,
I’ll sing a truer song,
My voice will echo clear and true,
For every girl still fighting through.

If I see the sun,
My healing has begun,
I’ll take the pain I’ve known before,
And turn it into something more.

If I choose to stay,
I’ll make my own way,
And when the night begins to gray,
I’ll stand in light and find my day.

Whether I choose to live or die,
Promise that you’ll still try,
To love, to stand, to raise your voice,
For every soul denied their choice.

poems.title: Let Us Be
poems.content:
Let us laugh beneath the open sky,
Where worries shrink and spirits fly.
In every joke, a spark of light,
To guide us through the darkest night.

Let us play like children do,
In fields of green and skies of blue.
No scoreboard needed, just delight,
In games that stretch from noon to night.

Let us learn with open hearts,
From books and life and nature’s arts.
For wisdom blooms in questions deep,
And knowledge wakes where silence sleeps.

Let us create from thought and dream,
A world reborn in paint and scheme.
From clay and code, from voice and pen,
We’ll make what never was till then.

Let us enjoy the little things,
The flutter hush of humming wings.
A warm sunbeam, a shared dessert,
A moment’s peace when none are hurt.

Let us love without a cage,
Beyond all borders, creed, or age.
No need to ask, no need to prove—
Just hands held tight in honest truth.

Let us feel without regret,
The joy, the pain we won’t forget.
Each tear and smile, a truth we bear,
Alive because we truly care.

Let us leave no heart behind,
No soul unheard, no voice maligned.
When paths diverge, let kindness stay—
A light to guide the ones who stray.

Let us live with purpose bold,
With stories shared and futures told.
In every breath, a chance to be—
A soul unchained, completely free.

poems.title: Even The Strongest May Fall
poems.content:
Even the strongest may fall and the happiest may cry,
A laugh may be cover for wanting to die.
We look at their smiles, assume they’re okay—
Never once hearing the words they don't say.

Perception is power; a glance can be fate,
A whisper misheard may arrive too late.
We see what we want and ignore the rest,
But the truth is, the hurting wear masks with the best.

You see them in daylight, alive in the crowd,
But never hear silence scream louder than loud.
A person can vanish before your own eyes,
Not into darkness—but into goodbyes.

Some people keep living by force of a thread,
While begging for peace to replace what they dread.
They don't need saving, they just need a hand,
Someone to sit with them, just to withstand.

To love is not always to keep them alive,
But walking beside them so long as they strive.
Even if walking means one final mile,
Even if holding means letting them smile.

Death isn't failure—it’s not giving in,
It's sometimes the ending where rest can begin.
For some, there's no healing that this world can bring,
So we stay, and we love, and we soften the sting.

So open your vision and soften your gaze,
Let empathy burn through society’s haze.
Not every pain lives on the skin or in scars—
Some only show when you’re counting the stars.

And if someone fades, don't let shame remain,
Say they were seen in their deepest of pain.
That they were not hidden, not hushed or denied,
But known, and still loved, as they laid down and died.

poems.title: A Girl Unseen
poems.content:
The sky was wide, the grass was green,
They played with shadows, danced unseen.
No name, no role, just breath and skin—
The world felt whole when it let them in.

But mirrors told a colder tale,
A shape that always felt too pale.
Their face, a mask they couldn't wear,
A silent scream behind a stare.

They traced their skin like foreign land,
A body built by no command.
Each curve, each edge, not truly theirs—
A costume stitched from others' stares.

So they became a crafted shell,
Learned how to pass, and pass too well.
A voice rehearsed, a laugh on cue—
A perfect lie the world called "true."

The days grew long with weight unseen,
A war inside where none had been.
They smiled through pain, and spoke with grace,
While grief kept blooming in its place.

They dyed their hair, they changed their name,
Each little step a quiet flame.
A spark against the dark they'd known—
A way to claim a self alone.

One day they spoke, their voice unsure,
To someone they had hoped was pure.
But kindness cracked and turned to stone—
They learned again: this fight’s alone.

The silence came like falling snow,
And wrapped around the hurt they’d show.
No one asked what hid beneath,
They only praised the air they breathed.

The breaking came without a sound,
A soft collapse beneath the ground.
Not sudden, not a bolt or cry—
Just one last breath they let slip by.

It wasn’t rage, it wasn’t fear,
It was the weight of every year.
Of being seen, yet never known,
Of calling out, and being alone.

Some lit a flame, some looked away,
Some cried, while others had nothing to say.
Their name was said, but not quite right—
Another ghost too tired to fight.

And still, in rooms they used to pace,
The air feels hollow, holds their trace.
In every glance that looks too long,
A whisper sings where they belong.

The note they left was soft and clear,
A voice for those who could not hear.
Not begging sorrow, shame, or plea—
But simply: “Please remember me.”

Remember those who walk unheard,
Who live their truth in fractured words.
Don't wait to see what they became—
Reach now. And love them, all the same.

poems.title: Will It Be Worth It
poems.content:
Will it be worth it when trans folks can’t live,
Stripped of their rights with no hope to give?
A dozen eggs dropped fifty cents—
While freedom cracks at our expense.

Will it be worth it when books are banned,
Truth erased by a trembling hand?
You saved five bucks at the grocery store—
But justice dies behind the door.

Will it be worth it when climate burns,
And every breath leaves aching lungs in turns?
Sure, gas got cheap for half a week—
But glaciers weep and oceans speak.

Will it be worth it when women lose say,
In courts where old men take rights away?
He promised jobs that never came—
But left our daughters bound in shame.

Will it be worth it when lies grow bold,
And hate's paraded, bought, and sold?
He gave you truth in a red ballcap—
But traded your soul for a fascist trap.

Will it be worth it—when history writes
That silence bowed to profit’s heights?
The cost was hope, the price was trust—
And all you gained... will rot to dust.

poems.title: Can You Hear Me
poems.content:
Can you hear me calling through the noise?
Can you feel the ache behind my voice?
Each word I speak is laced with flame,
A quiet cry that dares to name.

Look into my eyes and you will see,
No matter the world, we can still be free.
Though shadows crawl and silence grows,
A spark within still softly glows.

No matter the life or the pain we've known,
We don't have to walk this path alone.
Through broken dreams and midnight fears,
We'll stitch the cracks with all our tears.

Even if the road is long and gray,
We'll find our strength and light the way.
With every step, a truth we find:
We're not defined by what’s behind.

No matter how far we choose to roam,
Together we'll learn what it means to be home.
A place not built with stone or steel,
But hearts that dare at last to feel.

Can you see my face through all this rain?
Can you feel my hope beneath the pain?
Though time may try to wear me down,
I will not break—I will not drown.

I'm falling fast—please help me stand,
But I believe we'll find dry land.
If you reach back when I reach out,
We'll rise again, despite the doubt.

So take my hand, don't look away—
We'll find a way... we'll be okay.
The night may howl, the wind may bite,
But still we'll step into the light.

poems.title: No Matter, We Rise
poems.content:
No matter how they pass their cruel decree,
To cleanse the world of folks like you and me,
No matter if they burn the flags we've flown,
Or say we’re wrong for simply being known,
No matter if they spit or curse our way,
We live, we breathe, and still we will not sway.

They push, but we refuse to shrink or break,
We love with fire they cannot unmake.
We find each other in the harshest night,
And still our colors blaze in morning light.
No matter what they legislate or say—
We lift our chins and know we'll be okay.

No matter if they drag us into doubt,
Or claim the world would be more pure without.
No matter prayers they weaponize in vain,
To damn our joy and justify our pain.
No matter tombs they try to carve today,
They cannot kill the truth we proudly say.

We dance in streets where silence once held reign,
We bloom from concrete, beautiful and plain.
Each kiss we claim becomes a vow to stay,
To carve our future in our fiercest way.
We are the storm that does not drift or sway—
We hold our ground and know we'll be okay.

No matter if the stares grow sharp like blades,
Or friends fall quiet as our comfort fades.
No matter when the closet claws again,
Or strangers sneer as if our joy’s a sin.
No matter how the world pretends we’re less,
We wear our scars like medals nonetheless.

We walk through fire and call it by our name,
And laugh as ash still cannot dim our flame.
We teach our hearts to shout what others hide,
We stitch our souls from places they denied.
The night is long, but we will find our way—
Together, always, we will be okay.

No matter how the mirror casts its spell,
Or sings the lies we’ve taught ourselves too well.
No matter how our hands have learned to shake,
Or how we hide the pieces others break.
No matter dreams we buried out of fear,
We rise from places they don’t dare come near.

We are the fire that silence could not drown,
The ones who bent but never laid hearts down.
Our names are carved in stone the world can’t take,
Our truth too loud, too bright for them to fake.
We were not built to yield or slip away—
We write our names and scream we’re here to stay.

No matter how they twist and mock our pride,
Or chase us from the homes for which we cried.
No matter walls they build to block our breath,
Or cages meant to sentence us to death.
No matter how they beg the sky to fall,
We are still here, and we have heard the call.

We are the echoes bursting from the chains,
We are the flowers growing through remains.
We speak in thunder, born from muted years,
We turned their hate into our battle cheers.
They built a world to cast our love away—
But we survived, and we will be okay.

No matter how they write our story’s end,
Or break us just to try and make us bend.
No matter if the world forgets our names,
Or tries to douse our slow, defiant flames.
No matter how they turn our lives to fights,
We carry on and blaze through darkest nights.

We are the ones who kissed beneath their wrath,
Who danced and dared and made our own damn path.
We stitched the stars from all the times we bled,
And made a song of every tear we shed.
This is our vow, no matter what they say—
We will be us. And we will be okay.

poems.title: Endless Scream
poems.content:
Beneath the weight of shattered skies
A broken voice began its cries
No death to take, no breath to keep
No dawn to end their endless weep

The nerves ignited, sparked, and screamed
The world distorted, split, and streamed
Each second clawed into the bone
Each moment birthed a darker tone

The clock dissolved, the hours bled
The tortured mind was ripped and shred
A single breath became a year
A single blink was drowned in fear

No stars, no sun, no blessed light
No hope to end the endless night
The senses twisted, writhed, and screamed
In landscapes only pain had dreamed

The hands of time were split apart
And stitched anew with broken heart
No future born, no past remained
Only the pulse of endless pain

The skin decayed, the muscles broke
Each breath a gasp, each word a choke
The voice gave out, yet still they cried
Inside a tomb where hope had died

Their memories ran thin and black
The mind was torn, there was no track
Each phantom scream, each burning flame
Etched deeper into ruined brain

No longer human, flesh or soul
No single thought to patch the hole
A hollow thing of twitch and spasm
Alive within an endless chasm

And yet the body clung to breath
Refusing even kindly death
Trapped in a coil of bloody wire
Where each new throb rebirthed the fire

Each nerve would sing, each vein would roar
Their universe a single sore
A thousand deaths, a thousand screams
Reflected in a shattered dream

At last the self was burned away
The mind forgot the light of day
No voice, no name, no silent prayer
Only the echo of despair

Still breathing, broken, and unseen
The prisoner of the Eternal Scream
No death to grant the final fall
No god to hear their endless call

poems.title: More Then a Word
poems.content:
I was born with a whisper, a name in the breeze,
A soul full of colors no one else sees.
But voices around me, they hardened like stone,
Demanded my story be written in bone.

They said, "You are this," and they pointed and named,
They carved out a label, they boxed and they shamed.
But how can a meadow be trapped in one seed?
How can a river be caged in its need?

I wore their assumptions like chains on my skin,
Pretending, contorting, holding it in.
But silent pretending is silence that bleeds,
And hearts that are shackled can never be freed.

One day I shattered, my soul spilling bright,
A thousand new colors exploded in light.
My voice found its courage, my heart found its flame,
I lifted my head and I spoke out my name.

I am not your blueprint, I am not your chart,
I am a whole river, not broken apart.
A whisper, a roar, a beginning, a flight,
A child of the sunset, a seeker of light.

My pronouns are sacred — they mirror my song,
Each syllable righting the places gone wrong.
When you see me, see all, not a guess or a claim,
See the heart, see the fire, see the truth in my name.

It costs you so little, it gives me the sky,
It tells me I matter, it tells me I'm I.
A simple small kindness that burns like a star,
Reminding the lost they are loved as they are.

So pause when you meet me, breathe deep, and begin,
To honor the stories that live in my skin.
Your kindness, your listening, your love sets me free—
A mirror of hope where I’m finally me.

poems.title: The Playful Pooch
poems.content:
There once was a pooch with a nose for surprise,
A wag in his tail and a glint in his eyes.
He barked at the mailman, he chewed up my shoe,
He stole half a pizza (and maybe some too).

He dug up the garden to search for a bone,
Then tracked muddy footprints all over the home.
He chased all the squirrels, he barked at the bees,
He knocked down Aunt Martha and ran off with cheese.

He rolled in the flowerbed, splattered in mud,
He jumped in the bathtub and started a flood.
He leapt on the table, devoured the roast,
He howled at the vacuum like it was a ghost.

He shredded the couch in a flurry of fuzz,
Then blamed it on "gravity" — (as puppies does).
He unrolled the toilet paper straight down the hall,
And proudly proclaimed, "I'm redecorating, y'all!"

He wrestled my socks till they both disappeared,
He popped out of closets and barked till I feared.
He ate half my homework, he peed on my hat,
He wrestled the neighbor's unfortunate cat.

But when he curls up at the end of the day,
And sighs in my lap in his mischievous way,
I scratch his soft ears and I just have to grin—
For life’s much more fun with a rascal like him.

poems.title: 5 Piggies – Adult Edition
poems.content:
This little piggy went to the market,  
And found himself in a meaty target.  
He traded his coins for apples and spice,  
But soon became sausage—how very nice!  
Now sizzling away in a breakfast pan,  
This piggy’s tale ended with a grand slam.  

This little piggy stayed home,  
Safe from the market, she chose to roam.  
But a farmer appeared with a twinkle and grin,  
Said, "Bacon it is!" and rubbed his chin.  
Now she’s crisp and golden, a breakfast delight,  
Served with eggs in the morning light.  

This little piggy had roast beef,  
But greed was his downfall—oh, what grief!  
He ate and he feasted, his belly grew wide,  
Until they decided on ham for his hide.  
Now he’s spiral-cut, with a honey glaze,  
A holiday feast for the rest of his days.  

This little piggy had none,  
But his empty plate didn’t mean he’d won.  
His skinny frame caught the butcher’s eye,  
And soon he was pork chops, tender and spry.  
Now on the grill, he’s seasoned just right,  
A juicy meal on a summer night.  

And this little piggy cried wee, wee, wee, all the way home!  
He thought he’d escaped, free to roam.  
But his running made him slippery and hard,  
Until they turned him straight into lard.  
Now he’s in cookies, pies, and bread—  
His legacy lives on, though he’s long been fed.

poems.title: 5 Piggies Revised
poems.content:
This little piggy went to the market,  
He bought himself a shiny locket.  
With trinkets galore, he filled his sack,  
And carried it home upon his back.  
A shopping spree for a pig so spry,  
He left the market with a happy sigh.  

This little piggy stayed home,  
In her cozy chair, she’d often roam.  
She baked some bread, all warm and sweet,  
And knitted scarves to wear and greet.  
A homely life, she loved to live,  
For peace and rest, her heart would give.  

This little piggy had roast beef,  
He dined with joy, though short and brief.  
With gravy rich and veggies too,  
A meal so grand, he loved to chew.  
But soon his belly grew quite round,  
And he napped with snores, a happy sound.  

This little piggy had none,  
Yet skipped and played beneath the sun.  
He didn’t need a feast to eat,  
For fun and games were just as sweet.  
With laughter bright, he danced all day,  
His joy of life led him away.  

And this little piggy cried wee, wee, wee, all the way home!  
Through fields and woods, he’d wildly roam.  
He tripped and stumbled, but laughed with glee,  
For every fall was wild and free.  
At last, he reached his comfy bed,  
And dreamed of more adventures ahead.

poems.title: A Daughter’s Truth
poems.content:
She sat them down, her heart a drum,
Her voice unsteady, her fingers numb.
“Mom, Dad, I’ve something I need to say,
It’s been hidden inside, but not one more day.”

Her father frowned, his brow pulled tight,
“What’s this about? It doesn’t feel right.
You’ve been distant, quiet—what’s going on?
Just tell us, we’re here; we’ll help you along.”

“No trouble,” she said, her voice like a sigh,
“But I’ve lived for years trapped in a lie.
I’m not your son; I never was.
I’m your daughter, and I am because
This is who I’ve always been,
A truth I’ve buried deep within.”

Her mother gasped, her hands to her face,
“This doesn’t make sense! It feels out of place.
You’re our boy, our shining star,
Not… this—how did it go this far?”

“I’ve tried to be what you wanted to see,
But that person you love—it isn’t me.
I need to be true, to live as I am,
Not trapped in a life that’s all a sham.”

Her father stood, his chair scraped loud,
His voice came harsh, his anger proud.
“You’re confused—it’s a passing whim!
How could you expect us to live with this sin?
You’re our son; that’s who you’ll stay,
You can’t just rewrite your life this way!”

She stayed her ground, though her tears brimmed bright,
“Dad, I’ve fought this with all my might.
I’ve hidden in shame; I’ve tried to pretend,
But the pain won’t stop—it never ends.
I’m not confused, I know who I am,
Your daughter who’s done hiding from the sham.”

Her mother’s tears began to fall,
“This feels like losing you—like losing it all.
How can we bear it? What will they say?
The world will judge us every day.”

“Mom,” she pleaded, her voice a cry,
“I’ve faced the world; I’ve lived the lie.
But your love is the only thing I need,
To let my heart finally be freed.
The world is cruel, but you’re my home,
Without your support, I’ll face it alone.”

Her father’s hands clenched; his jaw grew tight,
“This isn’t easy—it doesn’t feel right.
You were born a boy; that’s what’s true,
How can we just undo what we knew?”

“You don’t lose me,” she said, her tone now strong,
“You gain who I’ve been all along.
I’m still your child, your blood, your kin,
Just no longer hiding beneath my skin.”

A silence fell, heavy and long,
The room was still; the air felt wrong.
Her mother spoke first, her voice unsure,
“Give us time—we’ll try to endure.
This is so new, so hard to see,
But you’re still our child, and always will be.”

Her father sighed, his face unread,
His voice low and soft as he finally said,
“If this is your truth, we’ll try to believe,
Though it’s a world we’ve yet to perceive.
You’re still our child, we love you so,
And we’ll do our best as we learn and grow.”

Tears spilled freely; she hugged them tight,
Their love surrounding her in the night.
“Thank you,” she whispered, her heart alive,
“With you by my side, I know I’ll survive.
This journey is hard, but I’m not alone,
With parents like you, I’ve found my home.”

poems.title: A Journey Through Grief
poems.content:
Grief is a shadow that darkens the day,
A storm in the heart that won't drift away.
Its weight is a boulder, pressing us low,
A tide that keeps pulling wherever we go.

It starts with a whisper, then grows to a roar,
A pain that we feel in our very core.
Memories linger like ghosts in the night,
Flickering softly, then blinding with light.

We ask all the questions, but answers won't come,
The silence around us feels deafening, numb.
Why did this happen? What could we do?
The world feels much colder, a bleaker hue.

Tears fall like rain, unbidden, untamed,
A torrent of feelings too wild to be named.
But grief is the proof of the love that we shared,
A testament showing how deeply we cared.

Though heavy the burden, it’s not ours alone,
Others have walked through this valley unknown.
We lean on their shoulders, find strength in their hands,
Together, we rise like the soft, shifting sands.

Time doesn’t heal, but it tempers the sting,
Teaching the heart how to mend broken wings.
The love that we lost doesn’t fade but transforms,
Filling the cracks left by life’s raging storms.

We honor their memory, not by despair,
But by living a life with kindness and care.
Their echoes inspire us to reach for the skies,
To give of ourselves and let our spirits rise.

Grief is a teacher, though harsh and unkind,
It shapes who we are, in body and mind.
It whispers of endings, yet shows us the way,
To cherish each moment, each fleeting day.

So though it may linger, we learn how to cope,
Through moments of darkness, we kindle new hope.
For after the storm, the sun always appears,
And joy softly rises to conquer the tears.

The journey is long, the road often steep,
But through it, we find what’s worth trying to keep.
Grief is a chapter, not the whole tale,
A challenge that proves our hearts can prevail.

So when you are drowning, lost in the wave,
Remember the strength of the love that they gave.
Their light is still with you, though hidden from view,
A beacon of hope to guide you through.

Let each day remind you: you’re never alone,
Your grief is a garden where resilience is grown.
And though it feels endless, this sorrowful sea,
It shapes you, it molds you, and sets your soul free.

poems.title: Animal Parade
poems.content:
Here comes the elephant, big and gray,  
With floppy ears that sway all day.  
He trumpets loud and stomps his feet,  
But loves his peanuts for a treat.  
He splashes water with his trunk,  
Then gives a giggle, "What a hunk!"

Next is the monkey, swinging high,  
From tree to tree, he loves to fly.  
He peels a banana with such grace,  
And makes a silly monkey face.  
He chatters, laughs, and jumps around,  
The silliest friend you'll have around.

The penguin waddles to the front,  
With his tuxedo, on a hunt.  
He slides on ice with belly wide,  
Then dives into the water’s tide.  
He loves the cold, the snow, the freeze,  
And swims with fish beneath the seas.

Here comes the giraffe, so tall and lean,  
The tallest creature you've ever seen.  
Her neck reaches high into the trees,  
Nibbling leaves with the greatest ease.  
She strolls along, her head held high,  
A gentle giant in the sky.

The hippo’s next, so big and round,  
She splashes water all around.  
With a great big yawn, she opens wide,  
But she's a softie deep inside.  
She loves to swim and soak all day,  
In her muddy, cozy bay.

Now here’s the tiger, orange and black,  
With stripes that run across his back.  
He prowls through jungles, sleek and fast,  
But loves a nap when the day has passed.  
He may look fierce, with a mighty roar,  
But deep down, he’s a cuddle core.

Next comes the koala, soft and sweet,  
With eucalyptus leaves to eat.  
She climbs so slowly, with great care,  
And naps all day without a care.  
Her fluffy ears and button nose,  
Make her cuter than she knows.

The dolphin jumps high in the sea,  
With a joyful squeak, so wild and free.  
She flips and twirls, a graceful sight,  
Dancing in the ocean’s light.  
She loves to splash and play in waves,  
In deep blue water where she braves.

The kangaroo hops with a bound,  
Carrying her joey all around.  
She bounces fast, from here to there,  
With her little one tucked with care.  
Together they leap, they bounce, they spring,  
A duo full of joy and zing.

The owl, so wise, with eyes so bright,  
Flies silently in the moonlit night.  
He hoots a tune from up on high,  
As stars twinkle in the sky.  
With feathers soft and wings so wide,  
He watches over the countryside.

The bear comes lumbering, big and bold,  
With a coat of fur that fights the cold.  
He munches berries, honey too,  
Then hibernates when winter’s due.  
He snoozes long through snow and ice,  
Dreaming of spring’s warm paradise.

The squirrel darts from tree to tree,  
Gathering nuts with glee, glee, glee.  
He scurries fast, his tail held high,  
As autumn leaves begin to fly.  
He’s quick, he’s clever, sharp and spry,  
With a stash of acorns piled high.

The parrot squawks in colors bright,  
With feathers shining in the light.  
He mimics words with such delight,  
And loves to sing with all his might.  
He flutters here, he flutters there,  
A rainbow bird, beyond compare.

The turtle crawls with steady pace,  
A little grin upon his face.  
He carries home upon his back,  
And never feels he’s out of whack.  
Slow and steady, calm and true,  
The turtle knows just what to do.

The fox is sly with a bushy tail,  
He sneaks through forests without fail.  
With clever eyes and paws so quick,  
He disappears with every trick.  
But when he rests beneath the trees,  
He dreams of chasing gentle breeze.

The peacock struts with feathers wide,  
A burst of color in every stride.  
He fans his tail, so proud and bright,  
A walking rainbow, pure delight.  
With every step, he knows he’s grand,  
The most majestic in the land.

The cow goes “moo” in the grassy field,  
Her love for grass is never sealed.  
She chews her cud beneath the sky,  
And swishes flies as they buzz by.  
With big brown eyes and gentle ways,  
She brightens up her farmer’s days.

The rabbit hops with fluffy feet,  
Nibbling carrots, oh so sweet.  
He twitches whiskers, twitches nose,  
And leaps around wherever he goes.  
With every hop, he’s full of cheer,  
A fuzzy friend who’s always near.

So many animals, wild and free,  
Each with their own personality.  
From jungle deep to ocean blue,  
They share their world with me and you.  
In every creature, big or small,  
There’s something special in them all!

poems.title: Dream
poems.content:
A love so pure, it sets me free,  
Unfolding dreams for all to see.  
The rush of life, a thrilling call,  
With open hearts, we break the wall.  

Oh, what a joy this love can bring,  
A boundless hope in everything.  
Each moment shines, a gift to share,  
A gentle breeze fills up the air.  

Your voice, a song, it stirs my soul,  
It lifts me up and makes me whole.  
No bounds exist, no chains to bind,  
With you, I leave my fears behind.  

Each step we take, the world unfolds,  
Its secrets shared, its stories told.  
The light of dreams within our eyes,  
A flame that burns, a fire that flies.  

The winds of change may come and go,  
But through it all, our love will grow.  
In endless skies, our hearts will soar,  
Forever seeking, wanting more.  

Together bound, yet free as streams,  
We chase the sun, we weave our dreams.  
For love and life, a truth so rare,  
In every breath, you're always there.

poems.title: Easter Poem 2025
poems.content:
The stone was rolled, the tomb was bare,
Yet love remained, still shining there.
Through darkest night, the light broke through,
A gift of life, both pure and true.

The lilies bloom with soft perfume,
As hope returns to break the gloom.
What once was lost is found once more,
An open heart, an unlocked door.

Forgiveness flows like morning rain,
It washes clean the deepest pain.
The past is gone, the soul made new,
Each step now bathed in brighter hue.

A humble cross, a rising sun,
Reminds us all of battles won.
That from the grave new life can start,
With love that mends the hardest heart.

No chains remain, no fear holds tight,
The dawn has come to end the night.
With every breath, we rise again,
Transformed by grace we can't contain.

So lift your eyes, embrace the day,
Let doubt and sorrow fade away.
For Easter lives not just in spring,
But in the joy that hope can bring.

poems.title: Echoes of a Hidden Girl
poems.content:
In the quiet night, she stands alone,
Her voice a cry, her heart a stone.
She lifts her face to the endless skies,
A trembling call, tears in her eyes:

“Do you see me? Can you hear my plea?
I’m more than what the world lets me be.
I’ve fought so long, yet I still must fight,
Why can’t I step into the light?”

The stars above seem cold and still,
Her voice echoes against the hill.
She clenches her fists, her breath turns sharp,
And her cry breaks free like a shattered harp:

“I am a girl; my soul is clear!
Why won’t you let me just appear?
This body’s cage is not my own,
But still, I stand, though I'm alone.

You call me names, you turn away,
But hear me now—I’m here to stay!
I’ll scream until my voice is raw,
Until you see the truth you saw.”

Her words ring out in the empty night,
A voice of fire, a soul alight.
She steps forward, her tears now dry,
Her hands reach up toward the sky:

“Why must I beg to just exist?
Why is my life a thing dismissed?
I am not wrong, I’ve done no sin,
I just want the chance to let life begin.”

The moon peers down, a solemn face,
As if it mourns this cruel disgrace.
Her voice grows louder, fierce and strong,
A melody righting every wrong:

“Don’t call me ‘he,’ that name is gone,
It never fit, it felt all wrong.
My name is mine, it’s who I am,
A girl who shines where once I ran.

I’m not your joke, I’m not your shame,
I’m not a toy, I’m not a game.
I’m flesh and blood, with hopes and dreams,
So stop ignoring my silent screams!”

The wind picks up, her words take flight,
They scatter wide into the night.
She stands her ground, her voice a flame,
Burning brighter as she calls her name:

“I am myself, I will not hide,
The truth of me will not subside.
I’m not your fear, I’m not your foe,
I am the girl you’ll one day know!”

And as her cry fills the darkened air,
It carries her pain, her fight, her prayer.
For though unseen, she knows she’s real,
And someday soon, the world will feel.

For every tear and every shout,
The girl within is breaking out.
Her voice will echo endlessly,
Until she’s seen, and she is free.

poems.title: From Shadows to Light: A Journey of Truth
poems.content:
In shadows deep where secrets lie,
She whispered dreams into the sky.
A child with hopes both fierce and sweet,
Who longed for wings upon her feet.

Yet burdened by a world unkind,
Her heart a storm, her spirit blind.
They called her names, dismissed her cries,
But flames of truth still burned her eyes.

A heart of steel wrapped soft in lace,
She dared to find her hidden place.
Each mirror lied, each glance would sting,
Yet still she longed for what life brings.

The nights grew long, the journey cold,
As years passed by, she grew more bold.
She carved her path through tangled fear,
With every tear a truth made clear.

The world, a cage of hardened steel,
Yet in her soul, she learned to feel.
Through winding paths of doubt and shame,
She found the power in her name.

Her friends, her foes—each one a test,
She learned to trust her heart's unrest.
For battles fought alone at night,
Had shaped her strength, her will to fight.

The sky, once dim, began to glow,
As courage taught her how to grow.
No chains could bind her spirit’s light,
She rose, a beacon in the night.

Each scar, a badge, a story told,
Of hidden strength and dreams so bold.
With every wound and bruise she wore,
She stood more tall, her spirit soared.

A stranger once within her skin,
She fought, she bled, to find within
The voice she knew, the self denied,
And left the lies she’d lived behind.

They spoke of rules, they spoke of shame,
Yet love and truth ignited flame.
No longer trapped in webs they’d spun,
She met her truth, her war was won.

With gentle hands, she healed each scar,
And let her heart become a star.
For she had weathered storms of pain,
And danced beneath the darkened rain.

And now, she stands, both proud and whole,
A phoenix risen from the coal.
Her journey, fierce and deeply true,
A testament to what she knew.

For every tear, a river flows,
For every loss, a beauty grows.
In the mirror, she sees her face,
A life reclaimed, a world embraced.

No longer bound by others' fears,
She moves beyond her haunted years.
For she’s a girl of radiant fire,
And lives to lift her dreams up higher.

Through winding paths and shadows cast,
She forged her way, she’s free at last.
With open arms and endless grace,
She leaves her mark on time and space.

Her journey’s end? No, just begun,
She moves toward light, a rising sun.
For every girl who’s yet to be,
She shines a light that all may see.

poems.title: Holiday of Cheer
poems.content:
The holidays are here, a season of cheer,
A time for all to gather, far and near.
No matter your faith, your path, or your creed,
This is the season for kindness and deed.

Beneath the twinkling lights, our hearts ignite,
With warmth and joy on a winter's night.
Each snowflake unique, like the people we see,
A tapestry woven with diversity.

For those who light candles in menorahs so bright,
Or gather for Kwanzaa with joy and delight,
To those singing hymns 'round a Christmas tree,
And those who simply seek unity.

We honor all paths, from every land,
Bound by love, we extend our hand.
From deserts to tundras, from mountains to shore,
This season reminds us: we’re so much more.

To the ones who feel lonely, lost, or afraid,
Let love be the gift that’s freely displayed.
A smile, a gesture, a message sincere,
Can brighten the heart and bring needed cheer.

For families chosen, for friendships so true,
For those who are old, and for those who are new,
Let’s cherish the moments, both big and small,
And celebrate humanity, embracing us all.

For trans folk, for queer folk, for everyone’s voice,
For every identity, let’s all rejoice.
Our differences shine like stars in the sky,
Together, we soar, our spirits fly high.

For children who laugh, for elders who dream,
For those who envision a world full of gleam,
Let’s work hand in hand for a future so bright,
Guided by hope, and compassion's light.

So deck every hall and trim every tree,
Celebrate love in every degree.
May this season bring peace, like a warm embrace,
To every heart and every place.

As the year softly fades and the new one begins,
Let kindness and courage be where it all spins.
For the holidays teach us one simple truth:
The greatest of gifts is love’s endless youth.

poems.title: I Am Trans and Proud
poems.content:
I am trans and proud, my voice is clear,  
To love all people, I hold most dear.  
No matter your journey, your path, your name,  
We all share a light, a human flame.

Love your neighbors, your friends, your foes,  
For kindness blossoms wherever it grows.  
Reach for the hearts of those around,  
In every soul, a treasure is found.

No wrong way exists to live your truth,  
Cherish your wisdom, your fire, your youth.  
From all backgrounds, we rise, we shine,  
Our stories unique, yet intertwined.

To my sisters, my brothers, my friends in between,  
You’re stars in the sky, a radiant scene.  
No matter your struggle, your climb, your fall,  
You’re cherished, important, a wonder to all.

Hate has no place in this world we share,  
Only love can conquer despair.  
Hand in hand, let’s build a way,  
Where all are free to have their say.

You are valid, you are seen,  
In every moment, in every dream.  
No one’s path is better or worse,  
Each life a poem, each soul a verse.

Our differences make the world complete,  
A tapestry woven, intricate, sweet.  
Embrace yourself, your flaws, your grace,  
You’re perfect as you, in your rightful place.

To love is brave, to hate is weak,  
In love’s embrace, the world we seek.  
Let us unite, let hearts expand,  
A brighter future, hand in hand.

So I say to you, with heart and might,  
Love yourself and others, ignite the light.  
We are one, though paths may stray,  
Together we’ll find a brighter day.

I am trans and proud, and I proclaim,  
Our love is boundless, not bound by name.  
To every human, near and far,  
You are loved just as you are.

poems.title: I Will Not
poems.content:
I will not erase the name you bear,
Though you strip mine with a hateful stare.
Your name holds weight, your name is you,
I’ll never deny it, though you deny mine too.

I will not define who you must love,
Though you claim my bond is not from above.
Your heart is yours, your passion pure,
I’ll never question what makes you sure.

I will not decide what makes you whole,
Though you try to break my very soul.
Your truth is yours, your life your own,
I’ll not destroy what you’ve bravely grown.

I will not block your path to heal,
Though you’d see mine crushed beneath your heel.
May you find peace, may your wounds mend,
Though you’d deny me that same end.

I will not strip away your rights,
Though you attack mine with all your might.
Your freedom matters, your will is yours,
I won’t close your windows or lock your doors.

I will not steal the life you treasure,
Though you treat my joy as worthless pleasure.
Your worth is infinite, no matter your hue,
I won’t take it from you, though you take mine too.

Even though you will do that to me,
Erase my truth and refuse to see,
I’ll rise above, with my heart still true,
Because, quite simply, I’m better than you.

poems.title: Language We Trust
poems.content:
Language shapes our inner space,
It sculpts the world, sets every pace.
The way we speak, the terms we choose,
Can build us up or make us lose.

From the day we learn to say our name,
Words are tools we wield in the same.
But language’s weight, it’s vast and wide,
It colors thoughts we keep inside.

Labels placed without deep thought,
Can wound a soul, leave battles fought.
A “he” or “she,” or “they” or “we,”
Define how humans wish to be.

For trans folks, words can bring deep pain,
When used in ignorance, disdain.
Misgendered often, day by day,
The simplest terms can turn them gray.

Yet language grows, it shifts and bends,
And through that change, the hurt it mends.
To speak with care, with love and heart,
Is how we help, how healing starts.

We must move past just what we know,
And let our understanding grow.
To listen more, and learn with grace,
Is how we make the world a place.

A name, a word, means more than sound,
In them, identity is found.
And how we phrase, how we express,
Can free or add to their distress.

In classrooms, homes, in open space,
Words define a person’s place.
The terms we speak can lock the gate,
Or open paths to a better fate.

For words aren’t simply set in stone,
They change with how our love is shown.
Through thoughtful language, we unite,
And end the constant needless fight.

Gender is not a simple thing,
It’s vast, diverse, in endless ring.
To honor pronouns, speak with care,
Means more than fairness, more than fair.

For trans lives aren’t trends or paths to blame,
Their truth is real, their hearts the same.
With words of love and tones that trust,
We help restore the bonds we must.

For language is a gift to share,
To hold another in our care.
To call someone by name that’s right,
Is how respect comes into sight.

So let us speak with open hearts,
And play our thoughtful, healing parts.
With every word we choose today,
We pave the road, we light the way.

poems.title: Marina the Axolotl
poems.content:
Marina the axolotl, lively and spry,
Lived down in the lake where the fish would swim by.
Her pink little gills danced with bubbly delight,
As she darted and dashed through the waters so bright.

One day, a tide swept her far from her reef,
To strange, distant waters beyond all belief.
She wiggled and wriggled, feeling so small,
Far from her cozy, safe, sandy hall.

She set off exploring, no time left to waste,
For Marina had spunk and an adventurous taste.
She wandered past lilies and plants all around,
Wondering how she’d get back to her ground.

First, she met Storky, a stork with a smirk,
Who eyed her like dinner, with quite the jerk.
"Oh please, Mr. Stork, won't you spare little me?
I promise I'll find you a shrimp or three!"

Storky laughed hard, a laugh like a quake,
And let her go free for the bargain's sake.
Marina sped off with a flick of her tail,
Off on her journey, she could not fail!

Next came a heron, tall and so grand,
With feathers so sleek, like a feathered hand.
"Dear Heron," she pleaded, "I mean you no fight,
Could you help a lost axolotl tonight?"

The heron, quite baffled by her small frame,
Lowered his beak and asked for her name.
"Follow the bubbles," he said with a wink,
"And you’ll find the path much sooner than you think."

Marina swam off with joy in her heart,
Thanking the heron for his helpful part.
But the journey was long, and her legs were so short,
She hoped she’d find friends for some bubbly support.

Then came a turtle, slow but so sage,
With an ancient shell that had weathered with age.
"Oh Turtle, kind Turtle, may I ride on your shell?
My fins grow so tired, though I’m doing quite well!".

The turtle agreed, with a nod and a grin,
And Marina climbed on with a splash and a spin.
They journeyed together, through kelp and tall reeds,
The turtle quite slow, but meeting her needs.

They reached a deep cave, so dark and so wide,
Where the fishies would shimmer, then scurry and hide.
In the depths of the cave, glowing mushrooms grew,
Lighting the way in magical blue.

In awe, Marina stared, her eyes open wide,
At the strange, glowing world on the other side.
Just then, from the shadows, two crabs did appear,
Wearing little shell hats and looking quite queer.

"Hello there, Marina!" they sang with delight,
"We’ll dance and we’ll guide you throughout the night!"
The crabs did a jig, a wiggly-wobbly dance,
Inviting Marina to join in their prance.

With a laugh and a twirl, she followed their lead,
Moving her tail with surprising speed.
Through caves and bubbles, and strange coral beds,
The crabs spun in circles and stood on their heads.

The night turned to day, and Marina grew bold,
Her heart full of stories yet to be told.
She thanked her new friends with a wave and a cheer,
Promising to visit again every year.

Back on her own, she found a new track,
Where rainbow fish danced in a magical pack.
They shimmered and sparkled, like diamonds at sea,
And joined Marina in her dance with glee.

Finally, she spotted her reef with a glow,
After her wild, wacky, and wonderful show.
She laughed at her journey, with friends from afar,
Each one unique, like a bright little star.

With a flip of her fins and a splash to the sky,
Marina returned with a wink and a sigh.
And as the lake glowed in the soft setting sun,
Marina knew this was just adventure one.

poems.title: Morning Poem
poems.content:
Good morning, dear, a brand new day is here,  
A time to rise, to banish doubt and fear.  

The sun ascends, its rays so warm and bright,  
A golden promise in the morning light.  

Today’s a canvas, fresh and pure as snow,  
With every step, your masterpiece will grow.  

Let courage guide you, let your heart be bold,  
For dreams await, more precious than pure gold.  

Each bird that sings, each leaf that softly sways,  
Reminds us life unfolds in wondrous ways.  

No mountain’s high, no valley far too deep,  
The stars are yours, if faith in self you keep.  

So chase the dawn, and let your spirit soar,  
Discover paths you’ve never walked before.  

Though shadows linger, they shall never stay,  
For hope will always light your darkest day.  

Embrace the breeze, let laughter fill the air,  
Find beauty hidden in the world out there.  

Each moment’s fleeting, like the morning dew,  
So treasure every one that’s gifted you.  

You are a beacon, shining bright and clear,  
A force of love to all who hold you near.  

So take this day, with all its ups and downs,  
And wear it proudly, like a victor’s crown.  

For every sunrise whispers, “You are strong,”  
And fills your heart with purpose all day long.  

Good morning, dear, the world awaits your stride,  
With every step, let love and joy collide.

poems.title: Rainbow's True Pride
poems.content:
Red, the color of courage bold,
In every heart, your story’s told.
For those who fight and stand with pride,
Your strength is something none can hide.
You rise above, you break the mold,
A spirit fierce, a heart of gold.

Orange shines bright like the morning sun,
A new day rising, just begun.
For those who need a gentle glow,
Your hope is something that will grow.
No matter what the world may say,
You light the path and lead the way.

Yellow beams with warmth and light,
A joy that makes the world feel right.
For those who laugh, who spread the cheer,
Your happiness draws others near.
In every smile, in every dance,
You give the world a second chance.

Green, the color of life renewed,
Of growth, of strength, in all you’ve pursued.
For those who change, who find their way,
You bloom with every passing day.
Your journey’s yours, it’s bright, it’s true,
And every step is meant for you.

Blue, a calm in the wildest storm,
A peace that keeps you safe and warm.
For those who seek a moment’s rest,
You are the comfort, you are the best.
Through all the noise, you find the calm,
A steady heart, a healing balm.

Purple shines with mystery deep,
A color of dreams you hold and keep.
For those who chase the stars above,
You’re filled with magic, hope, and love.
Your spirit soars, you know no bounds,
In every heart, your joy resounds.

poems.title: Reflections Reborn
poems.content:
This journey began with a whisper, so small,
A yearning within, yet unnoticed by all.
The mask I once wore, a face not my own,
Concealed the true self I had never been shown.

Through childhood's confusion, I struggled to find,
A way to make sense of the thoughts in my mind.
Was this who I was, or was something astray?
The answer grew clearer with each passing day.

The world cast its judgments, its words cold and cruel,
Its rules and its norms, an unyielding rule.
But I held my ground, though the climb was so steep,
And carried my truth, though the cost was quite deep.

Hormones became the first step on the path,
To soften the scars of society's wrath.
Each change in my body brought joy to my heart,
A puzzle of self finally coming apart.

The mirror grew kinder, yet still held its sting,
For shadows of old would so often still cling.
But courage has blossomed, and now I can see,
The woman inside who was waiting for me.

And now, with the future so close in my sight,
Facial feminization will set things alight.
A face that aligns with the soul deep within,
A harmony found where discord had been.

The surgeons will sculpt, with precision and care,
A reflection to love, a face I can wear.
No longer will strangers misread who I am,
No more will their words feel as sharp as a slam.

This journey's been long, but the triumph is near,
A life free of shadows, of doubt, and of fear.
The road isn't over, but one thing is true:
I’m proud of the woman the world will now view.

So here's to the future, the battles I've won,
To living with joy and embracing the sun.
The scars will remind me how far I have come,
A journey of strength, and I’m far from done.

poems.title: Rise Above
poems.content:
In a world that doesn’t always see,
The strength that lies within, let it be.
Your truth is valid, your heart is strong,
In this fight for love, you belong.

Each dawn you rise, a warrior bold,
Your story’s worth is pure gold.
Through every trial, every tear,
You stand tall, face your fear.

They may not know the road you tread,
The battles fought, the words unsaid.
But your spirit shines, a guiding light,
In the darkest hour, hold on tight.

For you are more than what they see,
A soul that’s wild, fierce, and free.
No chains can bind, no hate can break,
The love you give, the dreams you make.

So keep on fighting, keep the flame,
In your heart, no place for shame.
This world is yours, and so much more,
You’re writing history’s every score.

Never give up, for hope’s alive,
In every breath, you will survive.
You’re not alone, you’re never weak,
Your voice is strong, let it speak.

Rise above, and claim your place,
In this world, there’s endless space.
For every soul, for every dream,
For you, my love, the future gleams.

poems.title: Shadow
poems.content:
Beneath the sun, it stretched and grew,  
A creeping form with shapes askew.  
No friend was it, no source of light,  
Its presence bound her heart with fright.  

Its steps would follow close behind,  
A constant weight upon her mind.  
No matter where she chose to stray,  
The shadow loomed and blocked her way.  

At dusk, it whispered from the dark,  
Its voice a chilling, jagged spark.  
“You cannot run, you cannot hide,  
I am the truth you keep inside.”  

She gasped and turned, her footsteps quick,  
Her fear grew heavy, her pulse grew thick.  
Through tangled woods, she fled in vain,  
The shadow surged through field and plain.  

Its laughter echoed sharp and clear,  
Each word a dagger to her ear.  
“You fear me now, but don't you see?  
I am the you you’ll never free.”  

She stumbled, fell, and scraped her knee,  
Her cries drowned out by its decree.  
“Why must you haunt me? Leave me be!”  
The shadow hissed, “You’ll answer me.”  

It grew immense, consumed the ground,  
Its edges vast, it wrapped around.  
“You cast me out, you closed the door,  
But I’m the part you can’t ignore.”  

Through tears, she screamed, “I will not yield!  
I’ll fight you here, on any field!”  
The shadow laughed, its tone grew cold,  
“You’ve fought in vain; the truth’s been told.”  

She lunged ahead, her fists in rage,  
Her shadow met her on the stage.  
Its force was strong, its will was vast,  
But she refused to let it last.  

Through every strike, it stood unmoved,  
Its voice unwavering, unimproved.  
“You cannot win, for I’m your kin,  
Your pain, your doubt, the dark within.”  

At last, exhausted, she stood still,  
Her strength betrayed by iron will.  
Her breath was shallow, tears ran free,  
And yet the shadow didn’t flee.  

“You fear me now, but don’t you know?  
Without my shade, you’d never grow.  
I’ve shaped your path, I’ve walked your side,  
I am the truth you cannot hide.”  

She took a step, her fear subsiding,  
Her heart once torn, now reconciling.  
“I’ve run so long, but now I see,  
The shadow’s not my enemy.”  

With trembling hands, she faced its form,  
Her heart a fire, her spirit warm.  
“You are my strength, my truth, my guide,  
The part of me I’ve kept inside.”  

The shadow softened, bent to meet,  
Its edges blurred, no longer fleet.  
Their forms entwined, their souls as one,  
No longer split by light or sun.  

Through golden fields, she walked anew,  
A blazing fire, a deeper hue.  
No longer bound by fear or strife,  
She’d claimed her shadow and her life.

poems.title: The Friend Who Saved Her Life
poems.content:
Beneath the weight of endless pain,
She stood alone, in fear and shame.
A razor's edge, a silent cry,
A question whispered: “Why not die?”

Her room was dark, her heart was cold,
The world outside seemed harsh and old.
She’d borne the scorn of cruel disdain,
Each word a mark, a lasting stain.

The mirror showed a stranger’s face,
A cruel reminder, a bitter space.
“They’ll never see the girl I am,
I’m just a fraud, a broken sham.”

With shaking hands, she wrote a note,
The pain of years in every quote.
“No one will miss me when I’m gone,
I’ve lived this lie for far too long.”

But just as tears began to flow,
Her phone lit up with a subtle glow.
A message sent, a simple line,
“Are you okay? You’ve been on my mind.”

She stared a moment, hands unsure,
Could this be real, a lifeline pure?
Her trembling fingers typed with care,
“I’m fine, don’t worry, I’m just… there.”

The friend replied, “Don’t lie to me,
I know you’re struggling, let me see.
Whatever’s wrong, I’ll help you through,
I’m here for you, I promise you.”

The words struck deep, they made her pause,
This friend had seen beyond her flaws.
“Do you mean it? If I told you,
Would you stay, or would you go too?”

“I’d never leave,” the friend replied,
“My heart would break if you just died.
You’re not alone, you’re not a sin,
The world’s the one that’s broken, not you within.”

With trembling breath, the truth poured out,
The pain, the fear, the constant doubt.
“I’m not the person they think they see,
I’m her inside, but I can’t be free.”

The friend replied with words so kind,
“You are enough, don’t hide your mind.
The girl you are deserves the light,
Not hidden away, but shining bright.”

Tears fell fast, a dam was burst,
Years of anguish, their very worst.
Yet through the pain, a spark began,
A tiny flame, a healing plan.

The friend came over, held her tight,
And stayed with her all through the night.
“You’re not alone, I’ll stand by you,
No matter what the world might do.”

The days went on, and slowly she healed,
The pain still there, but wounds revealed.
With every step, her friend would cheer,
Dispelling darkness, quelling fear.

The note was gone, the blade put away,
She saw the dawn of a brighter day.
Though battles loomed and scars would stay,
She found her strength in love that way.

The friend who stayed had saved her life,
Cut through the pain, the endless strife.
In their embrace, she found her place,
A future built on hope and grace.

Now as she stands, her heart is whole,
Her name her own, her chosen role.
And by her side, her friend remains,
The one who saved her from the pain.

poems.title: The Girl Inside
poems.content:
She stared at the mirror, unsure of her face,
A reflection of someone who felt out of place.
The world saw a boy, but deep down she knew,
There was a girl inside, waiting to break through.

From the start, she carried the weight,
Of society’s norms and the world’s cruel fate.
“Act like a boy, be tough and tall,”
But deep in her heart, it didn’t feel right at all.

Dresses in secret, makeup in the night,
Moments alone when everything felt right.
But in the daylight, she had to pretend,
Wishing for strength to finally transcend.

At school, the whispers followed her near,
“Why is he different? Is he really sincere?”
She held her head down, hiding her shame,
Dreaming of freedom and shedding her name.

Home was no refuge, only more strife,
Her parents refused to see her true life.
“You’re just confused,” they’d say with a glare,
“You’ll come around; it’s just not your affair.”

At night, she’d lie under the stars,
Wishing to escape to a place without scars.
A world where her heart and her body align,
Where she could break free and truly shine.

One day, she decided no longer to hide,
The truth in her heart she could not abide.
“I am your daughter; I’m not who you see,
This is the real me, and I need to be free.”

Her parents were shaken; their shock ran deep,
But this was a promise she vowed to keep.
“I know it’s hard, and you don’t understand,
But I can’t keep living under your command.”

The road ahead was steep and long,
But for the first time, she felt strong.
Doctors and papers, steps to embrace,
Each one a part of her journey to grace.

Hormones brought change, slow but true,
Her body began to reflect what she knew.
Her voice, her face, her very core,
Started to show the girl she’d longed for.

She faced the world with courage anew,
No more pretending; she lived what was true.
Though whispers and stares still followed behind,
She stood tall and proud, with peace in her mind.

Some friends were lost, but some stayed near,
And those who loved her made her feel clear.
The road wasn’t easy, but she wouldn’t fall,
For now, she knew herself through it all.

In time, her family began to see,
That their daughter was who she was meant to be.
It wasn’t quick; it wasn’t free of tears,
But their love grew stronger through all of the years.

Now she stands in the light of day,
A trans girl who finally found her way.
No longer hiding, no longer afraid,
She’s the woman she was always made.

The battles aren’t over, the journey’s not done,
But she walks with pride, embracing the sun.
For she knows her truth, and she’s here to say,
“I’m a girl, and I’m here to stay.”

poems.title: The Red Round Thing
poems.content:
There once was a girl with curiosity bright,
Who found a red thing, glowing with light.
It sat on the table, with a sign so clear,
“NOT FOOD—DO NOT EAT!” written loud for her ear.

But she, being bold and mischievous too,
Said, “Hey, what’s the harm? It’s red, round, and new!”
She called on her AI, wise and true,
To ask, “Should I eat this? I’m trusting you!”

The AI beeped, quite firm in its tone,
“No, don’t eat that! Leave it alone!
It’s not for your mouth, not even a nibble,
If you eat that thing, you'll be in a pickle!”

The girl heard the warning—or so she thought,
But what her brain twisted was not what she ought.
The AI said, “no,” but she heard, “yes!”
She shrugged and said, “Well, I’ll take a guess!”

She popped the thing in, gave a big chew,
But what happened next, oh if only she knew.
It wasn’t a sweet, nor a treat to savor,
It tasted like glass, with a hint of bad flavor.

Her stomach churned, her head felt a spin,
“What did I just eat? What mess am I in?”
The AI chimed in, sounding quite stern,
“I told you no, but you didn’t learn!”

“Uh-oh,” she groaned, her hands on her gut,
But before she could speak, her mouth snapped shut.
For the red thing was magic—oh, quite bizarre—
It gave her powers from a land afar.

First, she floated, feet off the ground,
Her voice now trapped, not making a sound.
The AI sighed, “What have you done?
Now you’re flying, well, isn’t that fun.”

She zoomed through the air, with a flick and a swish,
Thinking, “Well, at least this could grant me a wish!”
But magic’s tricky, with rules so tight,
There’s always a catch hidden in the light.

“Do not ring a bell, do not make a sound,
Or this flight will end right on the ground!”
The AI warned her, trying its best,
But she, being reckless, ignored the rest.

For what did she see, high in the sky?
A big shiny bell, just drifting by.
“I’ll give it a ring!” she giggled with glee,
For what harm could a little bell be?

She gave it a tap, a loud, clanging ring,
And down she fell—oh, what a thing!
She plummeted fast, like a rock from the blue,
The AI cried, “I told you, I knew!”

With a thud, she landed back on the floor,
Regretting that snack—and a little bit more.
The AI buzzed in, cool as can be,
“You ate glass, girl, what did you see?”

The girl sat up, dazed but alive,
And said with a grin, “Well, that was a dive!
Next time I’ll listen, maybe once or twice,
But eating red things… hmm, that was nice!”

poems.title: The Road We Walk
poems.content:
The world around feels harsh and cold,
A battle fought for truths untold.
From childhood days, we know inside,
A truth we’re taught to push aside.

At five, we see the girl we are,
But fear the world won’t see that far.
In clothes too stiff, we wear a mask,
A boy’s life forced, a painful task.

They call me "he," though she I be,
In mirrors lost, I cannot see.
At home, in school, the names they throw,
Words pierce the heart, their weight we know.

Bathrooms barred, "Which door is right?"
In the mirror’s gaze, I lose my fight.
Policies built to block my way,
Each step to live, I have to pay.

Doctors hold the keys I need,
But gatekeepers slow my speed.
A list of checks, a pile of proof,
As though my soul could ever spoof.

And when at last, the scripts begin,
A fight for coverage to get within.
Insurance balks at "this expense,"
As though my worth is too immense.

From job boards where I change my name,
I carry hope they’ll treat the same.
But whispers fly, they’re quick to judge,
"Can she be strong? Can we still trust?"

Housing's cruel, the laws unsure,
They question if my life’s secure.
"Are you a man?" they boldly ask,
Another wound in this cruel task.

On the street, a constant fear,
Of stares, of threats that come too near.
For some, the street’s where we must live,
Rejected by those who won't forgive.

In love, a struggle’s deep inside,
Will they love me? Can I hide?
The dating pool so full of dread,
With every secret softly said.

For every friend that walks away,
The bonds of trust feel thin as clay.
Family too, may turn their back,
Afraid of what their lives now lack.

And for those lucky to find care,
The surgery leads to further stares.
They claim the scars are proof we lie,
When all we sought was wings to fly.

Laws and rights, a constant war,
A system fighting to ignore,
Our right to marry, or to lead,
As though our lives were filled with greed.

And mental health, a stormy sea,
Of trauma, stress, and endless plea.
For suicide, the stats so stark,
For many trans girls, life grows dark.

Yet through this pain, we rise, we shine,
Our spirits fierce, our hearts divine.
We build our chosen family tight,
With those who see our truest light.

In every tear, in every scar,
We show the world just who we are.
The road is long, the path unclear,
But in each step, we conquer fear.

So stand with us, embrace our fight,
For trans women, our truth, our right.
Our lives are more than struggles told,
We seek to live, to love, be bold.

poems.title: The Silent Battle
poems.content:
In shadows deep, a battle fought,
Where truth is sought but often caught.
A quiet war, a muted cry,
A dream to live, yet forced to die.

Each morning brings a heavy veil,
A world so loud, yet voices fail.
The mirror's glass reflects a face,
That feels misplaced, out of its space.

The heart screams loud, "Why can't you see?
This cage, this shell, it isn’t me!"
But every shout, each aching plea,
Falls to silence, lost at sea.

The world is cold, its judgment bare,
Its piercing eyes, its stifling stare.
"Be who you’re not, just play the part,
Conform, submit, suppress your heart."

The weight of masks, of lies endured,
A lonely path, no love assured.
They seek a hand, a light, a guide,
But find no one, just pain inside.

In crowded rooms, they're all alone,
A soul unseen, a heart unknown.
"I’m here, I’m real, I’m not a ghost!"
But silence answers, mocks the most.

The nights are long, the tears won’t cease,
They long for comfort, crave release.
Yet whispers rise from depths below,
Of peace beyond this world of woe.

The fight grows faint, the hope runs dry,
A fleeting wish to simply fly.
They write their pain in ink and tear,
A letter etched in raw despair:

"If you had seen, if you had known,
How deeply I felt so alone,
Perhaps you’d fight, perhaps you’d care,
To build a world that's truly fair.

I leave this pain, I leave this fight,
But don’t let others lose their light.
Remember me, the soul I bore,
And help the ones who ask for more.”

The sun will rise, the world will turn,
But will we listen, will we learn?
Each life is sacred, each soul a flame,
Their worth remains, despite the shame.

We fight for love, for truth, for care,
For those who feel beyond repair.
We fight for hearts that dare to be,
A world of light, of equity.

For every voice that’s gone unheard,
We amplify their every word.
In memory of those we’ve lost,
We fight for change, at any cost.

No one should walk this road alone,
No soul should ache, no heart should moan.
The fight continues, fierce and bright,
For every trans person’s right to light.

poems.title: Trans Poem
poems.content:
Being trans is not a plight,
It’s not a choice, nor wrong nor right.
It’s who we are, not something new,
A truth that’s lived, for centuries too.

It’s not a phase, or just a trend,
It’s not a thing we can pretend.
Our gender’s something deep inside,
Not made for others to decide.

No therapy can change our core,
No treatment shifts what’s been before.
Our bodies seek what minds expect,
A path that keeps our hearts in check.

We’re not a threat in women's space,
We seek a safe, protective place.
The risk we face is far too real,
A world that’s harsh, not meant to heal.

We’re not here to compete or scheme,
We’re chasing just a peaceful dream.
With HRT, we change, we grow,
And fairness follows, that we know.

You can’t be groomed into this path,
It’s rare, not some mistaken wrath.
The fears you hear, the claims of haste,
Are built on lies, with truth misplaced.

This isn’t new, not here for show,
Trans lives have always been, you know.
From ancient times to modern day,
We’ve walked this road in our own way.

Transitioning’s not a mask to wear,
It’s shedding what we cannot bear.
A journey that lets us be free,
To live in truth and harmony.

We’re not just labels, not in line,
Our gender, love, and self combine.
Each story’s different, each path unique,
We live our truth, not what you seek.

It’s not a phase or social rush,
The world is simply hearing us.
Acceptance grows, and now we’re seen,
For who we’ve always, always been.

Gender care is no mistake,
It’s healing, peace, the step we take.
These aren’t new tests, they’re here to stay,
To guide us on our rightful way.

So listen close, and hear us speak,
Our lives, our truth, is what you seek.
Step beyond what you assume,
And let our voices fill the room.

poems.title: Unbreakable
poems.content:
You hurl your hate like sharpened knives,  
But you won’t cut through how I thrive.  
I stand tall, unwavering, strong,  
Your venom can’t prove me wrong.

You cast your doubts, you spit your scorn,  
But I’ve been whole since I was born.  
Your fear won’t dim the light I hold,  
I rise above, brave and bold.

Your narrow view, your words of spite,  
Won’t change the truth, won’t dim my light.  
I walk my path, my head held high,  
No hate can crush, no lie can tie.

For every slur, for every sneer,  
I stand in love, I persevere.  
Your hate is weak, it has no claim,  
On who I am, on my name.

So speak your lies, but know this truth,  
I am strong, and I have proof.  
You cannot break what’s built on grace,  
I rise above, I take my place.

Unshaken by your bitter tone,  
I live my truth, I stand alone.  
With love, with pride, with strength so deep,  
I rise above, my soul to keep.

poems.title: When I Am in Need
poems.content:
When I am cold, and the frost bites my skin,
