When warmth feels so far, and the dark closes in,  
Will you be the fire to banish the freeze?  
When I am cold, will you put me at ease?  

When I am hot, and the sun burns too bright,  
When I’m scorched by the glare and yearn for the night,  
Will you be the shade that cools my despair?  
When I am hot, will you always be there?  

When I am sick, and the days feel so long,  
When weakness takes over, and I’m no longer strong,  
Will you stay by my side through the aches and the pain?  
When I am sick, will you help me regain?  

When I am lost, and I can’t find my way,  
When the world feels so vast, and my hope goes astray,  
Will you be my guide through the twists and the turns?  
When I am lost, will you help me discern?  

When I am tired, and my will starts to break,  
When the weight of the world is too much to take,  
Will you carry me through with your steadfast hand?  
When I am tired, will you help me to stand?  

When I am hurt, and my heart feels so sore,  
When tears fall like rain, and I can’t take much more,  
Will you mend my wounds with the love that we share?  
When I am hurt, will you always be there?  

When I am happy, and the laughter runs free,  
When joy fills the air like waves on the sea,  
Will you share in my light and let it shine through?  
When I am happy, will you smile with me too?  

Through cold, heat, and sorrow, through joy and despair,  
Our friendship’s a bond that’s beyond all compare.  
Will you stand by my side, no matter the test?  
When I am in need, you’re the one I love best.

poems.title: Will You Miss Me When I'm Gone?
poems.content:
Will you miss me when I'm gone?
When morning breaks, but I’m not dawn?
Will echoes whisper through the air,
Of memories we used to share?

Will you miss me when I'm gone?
When laughter fades, its warmth withdrawn?
Will empty spaces call my name,
Or will the world go on the same?

Will you miss me when I'm gone?
When time moves fast, yet feels so wrong?
Will shadows stretch where I once stood,
Or vanish, lost in faded wood?

Will you miss me when I'm gone?
When songs we loved still play at dawn?
Will melodies still spark a tear,
Or will they drift and disappear?

Will you miss me when I'm gone?
When seasons change and years move on?
Will autumn leaves still feel the same,
Or burn to ash without a flame?

Will you miss me when I'm gone?
When night returns but I am none?
Will stardust paint my love for you,
Or will you chase the morning dew?

poems.title: The Shadow She Became
poems.content:
“The Shadow She Became”
(AABB rhyme)

She ran through woods with trembling breath,
Each echo whispering tales of death.
The moonlight flickered, pale and cold,
While branches clawed like hands of old.

Her heart beat fast — a thunder’s call,
Each footstep ghosted through the hall.
The forest watched with knowing eyes,
As if it saw through her disguise.

The wind grew sharp, the stars grew dim,
Her vision blurred at forest’s rim.
She tripped and fell, her knees scraped red,
While shadows danced around her head.

She heard a growl, both low and near,
It fed her heart with ancient fear.
A shape emerged — her mirrored face,
But twisted, dark, from time and space.

She screamed and fled, but could not part,
For every path led to her heart.
The trees all whispered, “You can’t flee,
The one who hunts is only thee.”

Her breath came ragged, filled with pain,
As raindrops mingled tears like rain.
The forest sang — a mournful tune,
While clouds concealed the watching moon.

She hid behind a fallen pine,
The world around her out of line.
Her pulse a drum, her thoughts a snare,
The creature’s footsteps filled the air.

It came to her, both calm and slow,
Its eyes like fire’s gentle glow.
No claws, no teeth, no hate, no rage —
Just sorrow written on its page.

It knelt before her, soft and kind,
And whispered, “Why do you stay blind?
You run from truth, from what’s inside,
The self you’ve long refused to find.”

She shook her head, “You are my fear,
The voice that mocks me year by year.”
It smiled faintly, touched her hand,
And said, “No love can bloom unmanned.”

Her tears fell fast, her body froze,
The fear she felt began to close.
She saw within that phantom’s eyes,
Her younger self beneath disguise.

Each bruise she bore, each tear she shed,
Was birthed from truths she left for dead.
She reached to touch, the shadow stayed,
And light began to pierce the shade.

Her hands met warmth, her heart grew light,
The darkened woods turned silver bright.
The shadow’s form dissolved to hue,
A mirrored soul — her purest view.

She whispered soft, “I see you now,
I’ll wear your truth, I’ll make my vow.
No more I’ll flee from who I am,
No more I’ll bow to fear’s old sham.”

Her hair blew free, her tears turned sweet,
As dawn rose gold beneath her feet.
The forest sighed, its curse undone,
A girl reborn, her war was won.

No monster chased her evermore,
The fear she’d felt had closed its door.
For all along the beast was she,
The self she’d caged — now finally free.

And through the wind her promise rang,
A melody the morning sang:
“To run from truth is death begun,
To face yourself — that’s how you run.”

poems.title: The Storm She Made
poems.content:
Your bones don’t tell the life you’ve known,
they only guard what time has grown.
They ache, they mend, they fade away,
but never touch the words you say.

Your blood won’t mark your worth or pain,
it flows through loss, it flows through gain.
It doesn’t choose, it doesn’t speak,
but you still rise when you feel weak.

A womb’s no crown, no holy key,
it’s not your right to simply be.
They worship what can birth or bleed,
but miss the soul behind the need.

Your voice may shake beneath their gaze,
yet still it burns, yet still it sways.
They call it false, they call it loud,
but truth won’t bow, it won’t be cowed.

Your name may change, your shape may too,
but nothing steals the core of you.
They’ll paint you wrong, they’ll twist your art,
yet still you love with open heart.

Your body’s not their law to read,
nor bound by those who plant the seed.
You’re more than form, you’re thought and flame,
a force that dares them speak your name.

They’ll try to cage, to redefine,
to say your life can’t cross their line.
But every time they speak their lies—
a woman’s soul still testifies.

And when their walls begin to fall,
your truth will echo through it all.
For flesh is fleeting, fear will fade—
a woman is the storm she made.

poems.title: Bridges of Truth
poems.content:
Cry me a river,
Build me a bridge,
Your “facts” are delusions
Stuck under a ridge.

You shout about science,
But twist every word,
Pretending your hatred
Is reason preferred.

You talk about chromosomes,
Letters and strands,
As if they define me,
As if they command.

But life isn’t written
In base pairs or code,
It’s found in the heart
And the soul that I showed.

You say I’m not female,
But girl, I was born
In battles of spirit,
Through ridicule and scorn.

My flesh isn’t fiction,
My being’s not fake,
I’m realer than rules
That bigots create.

You cling to your comfort,
Your binaries rust,
But gender’s not cages,
It’s living and trust.

You cry over locker rooms,
Bathrooms, and games,
Yet I’ve seen more fairness
Than lives you defame.

You claim to protect her,
Yet wound her instead,
You silence the sisters
Whose tears you have fed.

Your feminism’s hollow,
A weapon, not grace,
You gatekeep your womanhood
While losing the race.

For woman’s not organs,
Not birth, not a chart,
It’s courage and kindness,
It’s fire and heart.

You’ll never erase me,
No matter your speech,
For truth isn’t measured
By what you can preach.

I’ll walk through your rivers,
I’ll burn down your ridge,
I’ll carve my own passage,
And build my own bridge.

I’m always a girl,
That’s all that I am,
Not theory, not label,
Not part of your scam.

So scream all your science,
It’s dust in the wind,
The future’s inclusive,
And I will not bend.

Your hate is outdated,
A ghost with no flame,
While love writes the story
And history remembers my name.

I rise like a storm cloud,
I shine like the sun,
Your war against truth
We already won.

Cry me a river,
Then watch as I soar,
I’m the girl you could never
Define anymore.
